example_quotes: Patient: I've been diagnosed with depression before as well.
Medical Student: OK, and do you take anything for depression?
Patient: I used to take a a citalopram, but I stopped and and things have been been stable.
Medical Student: OK, and do you have any issues with your bowel movements? Any Constipation or diarrhea?
Patient: No.
Patient: I I've had this cough that's been ongoing and and getting worse, and and now I've been having this like sharp pain in my in my chest.
Medical Student: OK and your chest pain, when did that start?
Medical Student: OK, and uh, would you describe it as, so you said it's kind of a sharp pain, does it move around anywhere?
Medical Student: OK, and are you feeling the pain when you're coughing or is it when you're exerting yourself, like when do you feel the pain, and how long does it last?
Medical Student: OK, I see, and do you have any pain when breathing in or out?
Medical Student: OK, and no chest pain on exertion?

Patient: No, it's the chest pain, well, I guess if I'm like moving around a lot, but it's not, it doesn't come on uh, like because of like physical activity. I just feel it like anytime I'm, like when I'm breathing in or even just moving my body around in the chair.
Medical Student: And how about any fevers or chills?
Patient: I I have felt a bit hot. That's more so yeah, maybe when I've been having night sweats, but I feel OK now.
Medical Student: OK, and before that were you getting any production throughout your coughs for the last few weeks, like were you producing any sputum?
Patient: Uh, no.
Medical Student: Can you just describe your cough currently? Is it more of a wet cough or dry cough?
Patient: Uh it, yeah, it's it's dry mostly with the exception of bringing up some of the blood.
Medical Student: OK, and do you have any issues with your bowel movements? Any Constipation or diarrhea?
Patient: No.
Patient: I I've had this cough that's been ongoing and and getting worse, and and now I've been having this like sharp pain in my in my chest.
Medical Student: OK, and when did the cough first start?
Medical Student: A couple weeks ago, OK, and has it gotten worse since then, or has it stayed about the same?
Medical Student: OK, and before that were you getting any production throughout your coughs for the last few weeks, like were you producing any sputum?
Medical Student: Can you just describe your cough currently? Is it more of a wet cough or dry cough?
Medical Student: OK, are you having any other symptoms at all besides the the coughing and the blood, like coughing up blood as well?
Medical Student: OK, and do you have any issues with your bowel movements? Any Constipation or diarrhea?
Patient: No.
Medical Student: OK, and uhm, other than these symptoms, do you have any kind of shortness of breath? Do you have any dizziness or increased sweating, any of those symptoms?
Patient: I have been sweating at night, but, uh, yeah that's it.
Medical Student: OK, and uhm, other than these symptoms, do you have any kind of shortness of breath? Do you have any dizziness or increased sweating, any of those symptoms?
Medical Student: Sorry, I think I might have forgotten to ask you a couple questions. So no fainting spells, no shortness of breath, nothing like that?
Patient: No, I haven't had anything like that, just a stern cough.
Medical Student: Sorry, I think I might have forgotten to ask you a couple questions. So no fainting spells, no shortness of breath, nothing like that?
Patient: No, I haven't had anything like that, just a stern cough.
Patient: but I have uhm, lost some weight and and I've been more fatigued over the last couple months.
Patient: No, I I uh, I guess I've been fatigued over the last couple of months, but I haven't had any flu like symptoms.
Medical Student: And any like fatigue or increased tiredness.
Patient: Yeah, I've had some fatigue for sure.
Medical Student: And how about any fevers or chills?
Patient: I I have felt a bit hot. That's more so yeah, maybe when I've been having night sweats, but I feel OK now.
Medical Student: Have you measured a temperature at all?
Patient: Uhm no I haven't.
Medical Student: OK, uh, do you have any other symptoms like a headache or nausea, vomiting?
Patient: No.
Patient: well, actually yeah, it's been getting worse 'cause now I've I've started to notice blood in the sputum that wasn't there at first.
Medical Student: OK, and when did you first notice that?

Patient: So I, I first saw some blood, uhm, two days ago. It was a really small amount so I didn't worry too much, but I I brought up blood yesterday and again this morning. It's been just about enough to cover a tissue, so it's not a lot of blood each time, but it's pretty red.
Medical Student: And is the blood just in like sputum that you're bringing up? Or are you coughing up blood into the tissue, for example?
Patient: Blood is, I'm coughing that up into the tissue.
Medical Student: OK, are you having any other symptoms at all besides the the coughing and the blood, like coughing up blood as well?
Medical Student: OK, and uhm, other than these symptoms, do you have any kind of shortness of breath? Do you have any dizziness or increased sweating, any of those symptoms?
Patient: I have been sweating at night, but, uh, yeah that's it.
Medical Student: OK, any issues with your sleep and appetite?
Patient: Uh, no. Sleep's been OK, and I've been eating well, but I have uhm, lost some weight and and I've been more fatigued over the last couple months.
Medical Student: OK, uh, do you have any other symptoms like a headache or nausea, vomiting?
Patient: No.
Medical Student: Do you have any other symptoms like feeling like pounding your chest, racing heart, anything like that?
Patient: No, nothing like that.
Patient: I have been sweating at night, but, uh, yeah that's it.
Medical Student: OK, and when you say night sweats, are your sheets and blankets like soaked your pillows?
Patient: Yeah, there there have been a few few nights for sure, but it doesn't happen every night. But over these last several months, it's been weird, I've woken up soaked.
Medical Student: OK, any issues with your sleep and appetite?
Patient: Uh, no. Sleep's been OK, and I've been eating well, but I have uhm, lost some weight and and I've been more fatigued over the last couple months.
Medical Student: Have you noticed any swelling in your extremities, like your legs and hands?
Patient: No.
Patient: but I have uhm, lost some weight and and I've been more fatigued over the last couple months.
Medical Student: OK, and have you lost any weight recently?
Patient: Yeah, I I have actually. I'm I'm down 20 pounds. I thought that was great. I I was 200 pounds just two months ago.
Medical Student: And have you been trying to lose weight or that 20 pounds just went away spontaneously?
Patient: Uh, I mean I I guess I've tried to make changes to my diet here and there because of the diabetes, but I don't really think that it would be enough to lose 20 pounds.
Medical Student: Any urinary issues?
Patient: No.
Medical Student: OK, uh, do you have any other symptoms like a headache or nausea, vomiting?
Patient: No.
